laws.summary: Utah does not have a statewide law prohibiting employers from asking about salary history.
requirements: Employers may legally ask about prior salary
Use of salary history may increase discrimination risk under federal law
Best practice is to avoid salary history inquiries
laws.notes: While legal in Utah, many employers avoid salary history questions for equity and risk reduction.

laws.summary: Utah does not require employers to disclose wage ranges in job postings or offer letters.
laws.statute_citation: No current Utah statute mandating pay transparency
requirements: Wage range disclosure is not legally required
Employers may choose to disclose pay ranges voluntarily
Federal equal pay and anti-discrimination laws still apply
laws.notes: Some multi-state employers apply pay transparency nationwide as a policy choice.

laws.summary: Utah allows non-compete agreements but limits post-employment non-competes for employees to a maximum of one year.
laws.statute_citation: Utah Code § 34-51-101 et seq. (Post-Employment Restrictions Act)
requirements: Post-employment non-competes generally limited to 1 year
Must be supported by consideration
Must protect legitimate business interests
Overly broad restrictions may be unenforceable
Employees terminated without cause may recover damages for enforcement attempts
laws.notes: Utah is more restrictive than many states but does not ban non-competes outright.

laws.summary: Utah does not have a statewide ban-the-box law for private employers, but federal FCRA requirements apply when using background check vendors.
requirements: Written consent required before third-party background checks
Must provide pre-adverse action notice before taking negative action
Must provide copy of report and summary of rights
Must issue adverse action notice if decision is finalized
Criminal history use must be non-discriminatory
laws.notes: Applies whenever a consumer reporting agency is used.

laws.summary: Utah does not mandate paid sick leave statewide but protects certain civic leave rights.
requirements: Employers must allow leave for jury duty
Employers cannot retaliate against employees for jury service
Employees may take unpaid time to vote if outside working hours is not feasible
No statewide paid sick leave requirement
laws.notes: Offer letters should not conflict with statutory civic leave protections.

laws.summary: Utah permits workplace drug testing and does not provide broad employment protections for recreational cannabis use.
laws.statute_citation: Utah Medical Cannabis Act; Utah Code Title 34
requirements: Employers may maintain drug-free workplace policies
Employers may prohibit impairment during work
Recreational cannabis use is not protected in employment
Policies must be applied consistently
laws.notes: Utah is employer-friendly regarding drug testing and cannabis-related policies.

laws.summary: Arbitration agreements are generally enforceable in Utah if they meet fairness and contract law requirements.
laws.statute_citation: Federal Arbitration Act; Utah Uniform Arbitration Act
requirements: Agreement must be voluntary and clearly written
Must not be unconscionable
Must provide reasonable notice
Courts may invalidate overly one-sided clauses
laws.notes: Fairness and clarity are key to enforceability.

laws.summary: Utah follows the at-will employment doctrine, subject to statutory, contractual, and public policy exceptions.
requirements: Employment is presumed at-will unless contract provides otherwise
Cannot terminate for discriminatory reasons
Cannot retaliate for protected activity
Public policy exceptions apply
Employee handbooks can create implied obligations
laws.notes: Clear at-will language in offer letters is recommended.

laws.summary: Utah law prohibits discrimination in employment based on protected characteristics and largely mirrors federal protections.
laws.statute_citation: Utah Antidiscrimination Act (Utah Code § 34A-5-101 et seq.)
requirements: Cannot discriminate based on race, color, sex, pregnancy, religion, national origin
Cannot discriminate based on age (40+)
Cannot discriminate based on disability
Harassment is prohibited
Retaliation for protected activity is prohibited
laws.notes: Offer letters must avoid language implying exclusion or bias.

data_quality.sources: Utah Labor Commission, Utah Code, Utah Antidiscrimination and Labor Division, official state guidance
data_quality.coverage_completeness: comprehensive for offer-letter and hiring compliance

additional_notes.general_guidance: Utah is generally employer-friendly but has a clear statutory limit on non-compete duration and strong anti-discrimination protections.
recent_developments: No statewide pay transparency law enacted as of 2026
Non-competes limited to one year under statute
No statewide paid sick leave mandate
Continued reliance on federal FCRA for background check compliance
